Megan Bontrager
CVPublicationsResearch


My research focuses on understanding the factors that shape geographic ranges, how populations adapt to their environments, and how species will respond to climate change. I approach these questions using a variety of methods, including large-scale field experiments, meta-analysis, landscape genomics, and climatic niche modelling.

I’m currently a postdoc in the Evolution and Ecology Department at UC Davis, where I’m working with Sharon Strauss, Annie Schmitt, Jenny Gremer, and Julin Maloof. My postdoctoral work focuses on:

  • How have life-history cues diversified across California’s jewelflowers (Streptanthus)? We are investigating how germination and flowering phenology respond to climate.
  • How have populations of Streptanthus tortuosus diverged across a wide elevational range? We are quantifying vernalization requirements and estimating their heritability, as well as investigating whether populations exhibit adaptive divergence in floral and germination traits.

I did my PhD research in the Biodiversity Research Centre at the University of British Columbia with Amy Angert. In my thesis research, I studied how climate, gene flow, and mating system shape the geographic range of an annual wildflower, Clarkia pulchella, in the interior of the Pacific Northwest.

I did my undergraduate work at the UC Santa Cruz, where I worked in the Parker and Kay labs.

Postdoctoral researcher, UC Davis
